First week UK sales on vinyl of The Endless River were the highest of any LP released since 1997, making it the fastest-selling vinyl album this century, according to official UK Charts data.
 
The BPI, the trade body which represents the UK’s record labels, has just announced that annual sales of vinyl albums have exceeded the 1m mark for the first time since the Britpop era of the 1990s, according to Official Charts data released today. The Endless River is at Number 2 in the current Official Vinyl Chart behind the David Bowie 'Best Of', Nothing Has Changed. Timeline Photos.

Pink Floyd's new album The Endless River has reached quite a milestone today, entering the Official UK Album Chart at number one, with a similar story in a number of other countries. If you are one of those who have helped with this achievement, what do you think of the album now you've had a chance to hear it in its entirety? Timeline Photos.

On Monday evening at London's Porchester Hall, the official launch event for The Endless River took place. Here are three pictures from the event, showing David Gilmour during the press call, Peter Wynne Willson setting up his light show, and the room itself during the playback of the album, showing off Peter's light show. summary: Many happy returns to Jon Carin, multi-instrumentalist who worked with Pink Floyd on the road since 1987, and has also been a key part of the Roger Waters and David Gilmour touring bands, who celebrates his birthday today.
Many happy returns to Gerald Scarfe, who celebrates his birthday today.
A very happy birthday to Gerald Scarfe, who celebrates his birthday today.
Many happy returns to Dick Parry, saxophonist with Pink Floyd for many years, who celebrates his birthday today.
Many happy returns to Roger Waters, former member and co-founder of Pink Floyd, who celebrates his birthday today.
messages: Many happy returns to Phil Manzanera, who celebrates his birthday today. An old friend of David Gilmour, in recent years he has been a key part of a number of David's projects, and also was a catalyst for The Endless River project. Here's a picture from the end of March last year, showing Phil on Mr Screen during a show in Toronto (picture: Gavin Elder). Timeline Photos.

A very happy birthday to Nick Mason! Founder member of the band, he has the distinction of performing on every Pink Floyd album, and despite being best known for his drumming prowess, also contributes vocals to a number of Floyd songs...but do you know which ones? Timeline Photos.

A very happy birthday to theoretical physicist, cosmologist, and author Professor Stephen Hawking who celebrates his 75th birthday today. Stephen's iconic computerised voice system can be heard on 1994's Floyd track, Keep Talking, and on 2014's The Endless River, Talkin' Hawkin' uses more of his comments about communication (which was also adapted for a UK phone company advert). You can hear the track on the streaming audio service Spotify: https://open.spotify.com/track/6GYRhhYSFv5eeqDkjOFN8c.

Many happy returns to Guy Pratt, who celebrates his birthday today. Here's a picture of Guy taken by Gavin Elder during the soundcheck for David Gilmour's Hollywood Bowl concerts early last year. Timeline Photos.

A very happy birthday to Dick Parry, the saxophonist who has long been associated with Pink Floyd. His first work with the band was for The Dark Side of the Moon, and here's his page from David Gilmour's 2006 On An Island tour programme... Timeline Photos.

Out today in 1979: Pink Floyd's double album of The Wall, reaching the number one position in many country's charts. Here's the inside of the gatefold sleeve, featuring a number of Gerald Scarfe's eye-catching, and chilling, drawings. Timeline Photos.
At this point in November, 1974, the band's UK winter tour was in full swing. Here's the poster for the shows, drawn by none other than Gerald Scarfe... Timeline Photos.

A very happy birthday to Aubrey "Po" Powell, Pink Floyd's Creative Director who made his name as part of the Hipgnosis album cover artwork team. Join us in wishing him a great day... Here's a shot of him from the 1970s, with Roger and David. Timeline Photos.
A very happy birthday to Roger Waters, 73 today. Here's a picture of Roger with David Gilmour; wonder what song they are contemplating here? Timeline Photos.

Many happy returns to Gerald Scarfe, the artist responsible for a number of Pink Floyd related artworks, most notably, The Wall project. Hope you have a great birthday, Gerald! Here's a video with Gerald talking about The Wall movie: Gerald Scarfe on Pink Floyd - The Wall movie. In this interview, Gerald talks about the movie of Pink Floyd - The Wall... One of a set of three exclusive video interviews with artist Gerald Scarfe for th...

Our very best wishes and many happy returns to David Gilmour, celebrating his 70th birthday today whilst in the midst of preparations for the upcoming North American tour. Today also marks the anniversary of the release in 2006 of his previous solo album, On An Island. Hope you have a great day, David! Timeline Photos.

Many happy returns to Snowy White, who is 68 today. Snowy has long been associated with Pink Floyd, joining the band for the 1977 In The Flesh tour (and also providing guitar on the 8-track cartridge edition of Animals), and later became a key member of Roger Waters' touring band. Timeline Photos.

Many happy returns to Phil Manzanera, who celebrates his 65th birthday today. The highly-respected musician and producer rose to fame with Roxy Music, but subsequently has had a long association with his friend David Gilmour, being a key part of the On An Island and Rattle That Lock albums and tours, and was a driving force behind Pink Floyd's 2014 album The Endless River. The picture here shows him during David's Royal Albert Hall concerts back in September/October... Timeline Photos.

Many happy returns to Nick Mason, who celebrates his birthday today. With thanks to fan site Brain Damage, here's a picture of Nick relaxing with his friend, Gerald Scarfe, who was responsible for the artwork for The Wall, amongst many other things. Timeline Photos.

Many happy returns to Guy Pratt, who celebrates his birthday today. Guy has played bass for Pink Floyd since 1987, and more recently has been an integral part of David Gilmour's band. Guy's career is detailed in his hilarious book, My Bass and Other Animals, published in 2007, which talks about his work with the Floyd in some detail. Timeline Photos.
A very happy New Year to you all! Here's to a great 2016... Timeline Photos.

Many happy returns to saxophonist Dick Parry, who celebrates his birthday today. Dick has been associated with Pink Floyd and David Gilmour since being part of Jokers Wild with David, in the days before the Floyd. David persuaded his friend to help out once with the Floyd, and Dick has contributed many memorable performances - live and in the studio - since 1973. Here's a recent shot of Dick, backstage at David's final London show in October this year. Timeline Photos.
A very happy birthday to Jon Carin, multi-instrumentalist and key part of Roger Waters', Pink Floyd's and David Gilmour's projects over the years. Timeline Photos.

A very happy birthday to Aubrey "Po" Powell, a key member of the Hipgnosis design team alongside the late Storm Thorgerson and the late Peter Christopherson. Between them, they designed most of Pink Floyd's album cover artwork. Many happy returns, Po! Timeline Photos.
Many happy returns to Roger Waters, who celebrates his 72nd birthday today. Timeline Photos.

A very happy birthday to Snowy White! Snowy was born in 1948, and at age 10, taught himself the guitar when he received the instrument as a present from his parents. Arriving in London in 1970, he became a session musician, began a lifelong friendship with Peter Green, and was recommended to Pink Floyd by Kate Bush's former manager when the Floyd needed another guitarist for the 1977 Animals tour. Since then, he's performed with the band on the 1980/81 Wall concerts, and more recently been a key part of Roger's live band. Timeline Photos.
Many happy returns to Dick Parry, saxophonist with Pink Floyd for many years, who celebrates his birthday today. Timeline Photos.

Many happy returns to Roger Waters, who celebrates his 71st birthday today by attending the first screening of The Wall Live, at the Toronto International Film Festival. There are two further public screenings of this concert recording, at the Canadian festival, tomorrow and next Sunday. 

Here's a picture of Roger with Syd Barrett, in the early days of Pink Floyd... Timeline Photos.

Bid for a once in a lifetime portrait of you or a loved one by the legendary Gerald Scarfe CBE, who worked with Pink Floyd on a few projects (most notably, of course, The Wall) who has donated his skills to Breast Cancer Care for Fab1 Million auction. The winner will send him a series of pictures of the subject, so that he can create a unique portrait. Bid here at http://t.co/mKBM3JX4RP. 5-4-3-2-1 FAB1 is GO! | Breast Cancer Care. Breast Cancer Care provides information and support for everyone affected by breast cancer. Find information, get support on our forums, donate and much more.

Many happy returns to hugely respected cartoonist and illustrator Gerald Scarfe, who celebrates his birthday today. Born in 1936, he started his career in the world of advertising (which he hated) before moving into political and social commentary cartoon work. Pink Floyd loved his work and used him for the first time for their 1974 British Winter Tour. Later, of course, his incredible imagery became a key part of The Wall project. Floyd fan site Brain Damage interviewed him about his career a few years ago: Gerald Scarfe interview. We caught up with Gerald for a long chat about his life and career. As you will see, his work with Pink Floyd was shaped by his experiences...

Many happy returns to Snowy White, who celebrates his 66th birthday today. Snowy first played with Pink Floyd in 1977 (as seen here), playing guitar on the tour, as well as recording extra guitar parts for Pigs On The Wing, which were used on the 8-track version of Animals. More recently, he's been a key member of Roger Waters' band for The Wall Live... Timeline Photos.
Very many happy returns to Nick Mason, who celebrates the notable occasion of his 70th birthday. Share your birthday wishes here... Timeline Photos.
We wish you all a very happy and healthy 2014. What is on your Floydian "wishlist" for this year? Timeline Photos.

A very happy birthday to James Guthrie, recording engineer and record producer, who has worked with Pink Floyd since 1978.

Quite recently, James was interviewed about The Wall from his perspective, and the interview can be read at fansite Brain Damage: http://bit.ly/1bDc9AF. Timeline Photos.

Many happy returns to Jon Carin, multi-instrumentalist who worked with Pink Floyd on the road since 1987, and has also been a key part of the Roger Waters and David Gilmour touring bands, who celebrates his birthday today. 

This picture shows Jon during the recent tour of The Wall Live, with vocalist Marky Lennon in front of him. Timeline Photos.

A very happy birthday to Aubrey "Po" Powell, part of the Hipgnosis design team who worked on many of Pink Floyd's album covers over the years. He is currently working on a book looking at the history of their work, with many previously unseen designs and photos of the different artists they've collaborated with. The book is anticipated to be published at some point next year. Timeline Photos.

Many happy returns to Roger Waters, who celebrates his 70th birthday today, in front of some 38,000 fans at Dusseldorf’s Esprit Arena where Roger and his band are performing The Wall tonight. Timeline Photos.

Many happy returns to Gerald Scarfe, who celebrates his birthday today. Well known to Pink Floyd fans for his work on projects such as The Wall and Pros & Cons, he is known around the world for his political and social commentary, through his remarkable and memorable caricatures. Timeline Photos.
A very happy birthday to David Gilmour today... Timeline Photos.

Many happy returns to Snowy White, who celebrates his birthday today. He first performed with Pink Floyd on the Animals tour of 1977, and these days is a key member of Roger Waters' touring band. Timeline Photos.
Many happy returns to Nick Mason! What's your favourite musical performance of Nick's? Timeline Photos.
A very happy New Year to you all. What are your hopes for 2013? Pink Floyd. Happy New Year!

Many happy returns to Jon Carin, multi-instrumentalist, who celebrates his birthday today. Jon has been a core part of the respective bands of Pink Floyd, Roger Waters, and David Gilmour, particularly on the road.

Many happy returns to Roger Waters, former member and co-founder of Pink Floyd, who celebrates his birthday today. It's also the sixth anniversary of the start of his North American tour of The Dark Side Of The Moon, which took place in New Jersey on the evening of his birthday. Of course, more recently he's been performing The Wall live, and this picture was taken before the final 2012 concert: Timeline Photos.

A very happy birthday to Gerald Scarfe, who celebrates his birthday today. Gerald is best known amongst Floyd fans for his work on projects such as The Wall, and Roger's Pros & Cons Of Hitchhiking. Timeline Photos.

Today is your last chance to submit a question for Gerald Scarfe. Please post it here as a comment on this thread, and all submitted questions this week will then be collated for Gerald to answer a selection of.

Gerald Scarfe is best known in the world of Floyd for his work on The Wall, but he has been involved with the band since 1974. Following on from our Q&A with Storm Thorgerson, we're now giving you the opportunity to ask Gerald that question you've always been wondering about. Please post them here as comments on this thread, by the end of Friday, and a selection of the best questions will be given to Gerald for him to answer. His reponses will then be posted here for you all to enjoy... Timeline Photos.

A very happy birthday to guitarist Snowy White, who celebrates his birthday today. Snowy first performed with Pink Floyd back in 1977, and is a core member of Roger Waters' touring band to this day. Timeline Photos.
Many happy returns to Nick Mason, who celebrates his birthday today (January 27th). Timeline Photos.

In March 1973, Pink Floyd were performing The Dark Side of the Moon to North American audiences, and on this day, did a midnight show in New York's Radio City Music Hall. Timeline Photos.
In 1973, the press reception for The Dark Side of the Moon was held at London Planetarium, now part of Madame Tussaud's waxwork museum. Timeline Photos.

Amongst the better known of the early seventies concerts, were the set of four performed at London's Rainbow Theatre. Coming almost a month after the start of The Dark Side of the Moon tour, the press premiere of their new creation took place on this day in 1972. Here's the scarce (free) programme for their shows there. Timeline Photos.
The live debut of The Dark Side of the Moon... Timeline Photos.

For our final look back this week at The Dark Side of the Moon, here's part of the Discovery/Experience/Immersion release programme from September 2011. Three Immersion box sets were created, including this one for Dark Side. Released for the first time on CD/DVD/Blu-ray were live tracks, high resolution audio and video material including various surround mixes, screen films, demos and early live versions... Timeline Photos.

Twelve years ago, to mark the 30th anniversary of the album, a special edition hybrid SACD of The Dark Side of the Moon was released, featuring a new surround mix. Did you know that the stained-glass window on the cover was photographed in Nick Mason's garden? Timeline Photos.

In 2009, to help publicise a screening of PULSE on Sky Arts 1 HD, and specifically the Dark Side of the Moon segment of the show, a 5-metre high 'prism' was created with diffused LED lighting. Lasers were installed behind the structure, a white laser emitting from the left hand side and coloured beams emitting from the right hand side, to re-create the image which looked like this: Timeline Photos.

Today in 1972 saw the press launch of The Dark Side of the Moon as a complete piece of music. It was presented during the first of four nights at London's Rainbow Theatre. The UK tour poster had a typically playful picture of the band, with their backs to the camera... Timeline Photos.

Richard Wright, 1996:
"The late 60's was a purely experimental time in the band's history. But it was a learning process. By the 70's we'd consolidated ourselves and we knew what we could do: what we could write, what we could play. Dark Side Of The Moon and Wish You Were Here was a very enjoyable time. Looking back now, though, it was also a very busy time, so I don't think we ever had much chance to sit back and think about what we were doing. Throughout the whole of the early '70s, we were either on the road or in a recording studio. That's all I can remember."

Today in 1969, Pink Floyd performed at the Brighton Dome along with “their Azimuth Co-ordinator” which drove their quadrophonic surround effects during the show. The venue, once the stables for the adjacent Royal Pavilion, proved a favourite on the south coast for the band, who performed there a few times, most notably at the (ill-fated) start of the 1972 tour of The Dark Side of the Moon where the first public performance of the work only got as far as the start of Money…. Timeline Photos.

During his 2006 The Dark Side of the Moon tour, Roger Waters performed at the Kindl-Buhne, Wuhlheide, on the outskirts of Berlin. In a moment of perfect timing, as he performed the closing part of the album (Brain Damage and Eclipse) the moon was spotted in perfect position just above the stage, displaying its dark side... Timeline Photos.

This date saw three commemorative editions of The Dark Side of the Moon released - in 1993, the 20th anniversary package, and in 2003, the 30th anniversary Super Audio CD and special vinyl edition. Timeline Photos.

In 1973, Pink Floyd's The Dark Side of the Moon was released. A rough version of the track Brain Damage was written around the time of Meddle and was actually known as "The Dark Side of the Moon". For the 40th anniversary of the album, a collage was made of various alternate takes on the iconic prism image. Timeline Photos.

The 1977 In The Flesh European tour, featuring Animals, was in full swing by this stage in March, and on this day they performed at Wembley's Empire Pool (later renamed Wembley Arena). A special edition of The Dark Side of the Moon was put together at the end of that year for the Japanese market, and included this shot of the band live as the cover. Timeline Photos.

Pink Floyd started the first of a four-night run at London's Rainbow Theatre (which is now a Brazilian Pentecostal church), on this day in 1972. It was the premiere to the press of the then work-in-progress suite, The Dark Side of the Moon. Timeline Photos.

This day in 1972 saw the first attempt to perform The Dark Side of the Moon live. The concert, at the Brighton Dome on the south coast of England, was beset by what Roger Waters called "severe mechanical and electric horror". This resulted in Dark Side being scrapped during Money and some older tracks being hastily brought into the setlist. This picture was taken backstage at the Dome in 1972 by Jill Furmanovsky. Timeline Photos.

We hope you have enjoyed all the prisms posted over the last couple of weeks, celebrating the 40th anniversary of The Dark Side Of The Moon. Visit pinkfloyd.com now to see what it was all about… http://smarturl.it/darkside40f. Timeline Photos.

This Sunday marks the 40th anniversary of The Dark Side Of The Moon. Help us turn the moon dark on pinkfloyd.com by tweeting your thoughts, memories and photos using #DarkSide40 - tweeting starts 24th March. Timeline Photos.
Celebrate the 40th anniversary of The Dark Side of the Moon this Sunday: http://bit.ly/15l3c96. Timeline Photos.

Due to the popularity of our recent Wall on vinyl competition, we thought we'd run another quick contest to this time give away a copy of The Dark Side Of The Moon. Entries need to be placed by midnight on Thursday. Click here: http://bit.ly/13OgASu. Timeline Photos.

David Gilmour recently gave an interview to coincide with Babington House playing The Dark Side Of The Moon in its entirety on high-end audio equipment. The following link gives more detail on the event, together with a link to listen to David's interview, which runs for 25 minutes. You will need to complete the (free) registration before you can access the interview. Pink Floyd at Babington House (courtesy of high50) Dark Side of the Moon was the chosen album for our second record listening club, held in the beautiful library at Babington House. Daniela Soave reports. Plus: hear the recording of our exclusive interview with David Gilmour.
Money was released as a single in the US, today in 1973. Pink Floyd - Money. Money is from the 1973 Pink Floyd album The Dark Side Of The Moon.

The 1975 North American Wish You Were Here Tour started today in Vancouver. Included in the set alongside the newly released album were Echoes, Raving And Drooling, and You've Got To Be Crazy, as well as Dark Side Of The Moon. Quite a set - did you see them on this tour? Timeline Photos.

Less than two weeks remain of "Dark Side Of The Moon - A Photographic Exhibition" which is on display at The Dome, Brighton, England, where the first live performance of the album was attempted 40 years ago on January 20th, 1972. Brighton Dome - Dark Side of the Moon Brighton. On occasions the Foyer may be closed for a private function. Please call 01273 700747 in advance of your visit to check.   Celebrating the 40th anniversary of Pink Floyds first performance of this seminal album, which took place on 20th January 1972 at the Brighton Dome.   Photographer Jill Furmanov...

Ian Emes, who created the celebrated 'flying clocks' sequence in Time for the Dark Side Of The Moon concert screen films, has launched his own exhibition in London, presented as an "immersive installation". Emes also created the 'French Windows' animation based on One Of These Days, and was an advisor on The Wall film. Staged at the Unit 24 Gallery, 20 Great Guildford Street, London SE1 0FD, the exhibition runs until March 28, and is free. More info here: http://unit24.info. Timeline Photos.
It's the 40th anniversary of the start of Pink Floyd's The Dark Side Of The Moon tour, with a show beset with problems in Brighton. http://bit.ly/xPxwmI. Timeline Photos.

Dark Side Of The Moon - A Photographic Exhibition marks the 40th anniversary of Pink Floyd's first attempted public performance of this album on January 20th 1972 at the Brighton Dome. The exhibition runs from January 20th to March 20th, 2012, at the Founders Room at the Dome, between 10am - 5pm, Tuesday through to Sunday, each week. Admission is free. Photographer Jill Furmanovsky spent considerable time on the road with the band that year, and the exhibition will display a range of her pictures, along with other rare and intimate images by Storm Thorgerson, Colin Prime and Tony Collins.
On the opening evening, there will be a Q&A with Jill, again being hosted in the Founders Room in the Dome. This starts at 7pm, and is also free: Brighton Dome - Dark Side of the Moon Brighton Tickets. Celebrating the 40th anniversary of Pink Floyds first performance of this seminal album, which took place on 20th January 1972 at the Brighton Dome.   Photographer Jill Furmanovsky spent considerable time on the road with the band including the debut gig of Dark Side of the Moon gig in Brighton.   T...

summary: The Madcap Laughs, Syd Barrett's first solo album, was released in the UK on this day, 1970.

Programme website: http://bbc.in/1Qjb7yQ David Gilmour talks about his early musical influences, being given a Bob Dylan album from his parents, and learning... If you saw any of David Gilmour's recent European concerts, or are looking forward to seeing him at the end of this year, or next year, and want to remind yourself of one of his earlier shows, the David Gilmour In Concert app for Apple and Android devices could be ideal, and provides an acoustic alternative to the shows he has performed this year - an interesting contrast to how you may have heard some of the tracks performed in the past.
The last of three nights at the Royal Albert Hall at the end of May on the 2006 David Gilmour tour, saw Nick Mason joining the band on stage for encores of Wish You Were Here and Comfortably Numb.
It's also the anniversary of the release of his last solo album, On An Island, in 2006.
In 1973, Pink Floyd's The Dark Side Of The Moon was released in the UK on this day.
messages: Please join us in wishing David Gilmour a great birthday! It's also the anniversary of the release of On An Island, which came out eleven years ago. How time flies! Timeline Photos.
Today in 1984, David Gilmour's second solo album About Face was released. There were two singles released; do you know what songs were selected for these? Timeline Photos.
Today in 1970, Syd Barrett's debut solo album, The Madcap Laughs, was released. Here's the advert which appeared for it at the time... Timeline Photos.
An interesting look at Pink Floyd in their earlier days: Timeline Photos.
Today we take a look at a very rare single release on this day in 1969 from Syd Barrett - Octopus, coupled with Golden Hair... Timeline Photos.

Last night, the Cambridge Corn Exchange saw Syd Barrett's family, friends, and fans all come together for a celebration of the man and his music. The concert featured Swedish band Men on the Border performing Syd's songs, as well as a few of their own, backed by the 50-piece Sandviken Symphony Orchestra. Lighting was provided by Peter Wynne-Willson who worked with Pink Floyd between 1966-1968.

A permanently sited artwork, a memorial to Syd, was also unveiled in the foyer of the Corn Exchange. Timeline Photos.

In 1985, Profiles, a collaboration between Nick Mason, and 10cc guitarist Rick Fenn, was released. One of the tracks – Lie for a Lie – featured David Gilmour and vocalist Maggie Reilly, both of whom seen in the promo video created at the time. Here's a rare Canadian 12" edition of the single. Timeline Photos.
In August 1965, Syd Barrett and David Gilmour busked around Spain and France, performing Beatles songs. Which ones do you think they may have had as part of their repertoire?

Celebrate Syd Barrett and Pink Floyd in the range of postage stamps released today by the UK's Royal Mail:

http://www.royalmail.com/pinkfloydstamps?cid=EC0516_MGP_SM_01. Timeline Photos.

On this day in 1970, Syd Barrett appeared at London's Olympia, playing his first concert since leaving Pink Floyd. The show, part of the four day Extravaganza 70 at the venue, included his old friend David Gilmour on guitar, but ended suddenly during the fourth song when Syd took off his guitar and walked off stage. Timeline Photos.

Today we mark the 35th anniversary of the release of Nick Mason’s Fictitious Sports album, recorded in conjunction with Carla Bley, who also wrote all the songs. Robert Wyatt featured as vocalist on most of the tracks…. Timeline Photos.

Here's an audience recording of David Gilmour performing Comfortably Numb last night, with the inclusion of Purple Rain as a tribute to Prince: David Gilmour - Comfortably Numb (featuring Purple Rain) On Sunday, April 24th 2016 David Gilmour performed for Teenage Cancer Trust at the Royal Albert Hall. This is an audience recording of David Gilmour performi...

In 2001, The Best of Syd Barrett: Wouldn't You Miss Me? was released. More a starting point for the casual Syd fan to explore various facets of his music, it did have the surprise inclusion of the previously unreleased Bob Dylan Blues, from David Gilmour's personal collection. Timeline Photos.

Here's another song performed live by David Gilmour on the Jimmy Kimmel Live! show - Wish You Were Here... David Gilmour Performs "Wish You Were Here" David Gilmour Performs "Wish You Were Here" on Jimmy Kimmel Live Deleted Scene from "Batman v Superman” Starring Jimmy Kimmel - https://www.youtube.com/watch...

A new interview with David... David Gilmour on Pink Floyd, Rattle That Lock & Syd Barrett. Legendary Pink Floyd guitarist, vocalist and writer David Gilmour discusses his musical career from Jokers Wild to Pink Floyd. Gilmour also recalls Syd Barre...

The work behind creating some of Pink Floyd's iconic imagery can be fascinating. This video shows how the giant head, used in the High Hopes promo film and representing Syd Barrett, was created... Syd Barrett Sculpture The Division Bell by Sculpture Studios. For more of our work, visit http://www.SculptureStudios.co.uk 'Like' us on Facebook https://www.Facebook.com/sculpturestudios Subscribe to our Youtube channe...

Today we're marking what would have been the 70th birthday of Roger Keith “Syd” Barrett, with the launch of a newly designed, official website. www.SydBarrett.com will offer a wealth of previously unseen family photographs documenting Syd from early childhood until the early 1980s. Syd Barrett | The Official Website of Syd Barrett, the original front man and songwriter for... Official Website of Syd Barrett, the original front man and songwriter for Pink Floyd.
In 1970, Syd Barrett's The Madcap Laughs, his first solo album, was released. What's your favourite track from the album? Timeline Photos.

On this day in 1965, Syd Barrett performed with Those Without at a wedding reception in Cambridge. This picture from that event shows Syd, Robert Smith – known as Smudge – on rhythm guitar, and Stephen Pyle on drums: Timeline Photos.

As we've already mentioned, tonight at 9:45pm the UK's BBC2 television channel airs Wider Horizons, a 75 minute documentary looking at David Gilmour's life and career. For those in the UK and Europe who are able to tune in to this show, here's more information about what to expect, and is where the show will be available to stream online in many regions, after broadcast: http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b06pyrbs. David Gilmour: Wider Horizons - BBC Two. An intimate portrait of guitarist and singer David Gilmour.

Next Saturday, November 14th, David Gilmour is the subject of an extensive documentary on the UK's BBC2 television channel. Here's a preview of the programme: David Gilmour on learning to play guitar - David Gilmour: Wider Horizons: Preview - BBC Two. Programme website: http://bbc.in/1Qjb7yQ David Gilmour talks about his early musical influences, being given a Bob Dylan album from his parents, and learning...

If you saw any of David Gilmour's recent European concerts, or are looking forward to seeing him at the end of this year, or next year, and want to remind yourself of one of his earlier shows, the David Gilmour In Concert app for Apple and Android devices could be ideal, and provides an acoustic alternative to the shows he has performed this year - an interesting contrast to how you may have heard some of the tracks performed in the past. Here's what the app consists of: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kBYfUJrUP3A. 'David Gilmour In Concert' App Trailer. Official trailer for the 'David Gilmour In Concert' App. Available from 19th November 2012 on the Apple App Store, and for Android devices. Click here to fin...

Following on from yesterday's post, here's another of David's performances on BBC TV's Later...with Jools Holland, the song Today: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GN_90sarGGI. David Gilmour - Today - Later… with Jools Holland - BBC Two. See more at http://www.bbc.co.uk/later David Gilmour performs Today on Later… with Jools Holland, BBC Two (29 September 2015)

A much loved solo album was released today – Richard Wright's Broken China. Released in 1996, the album sessions included David Gilmour contributing guitar on the track Breakthrough, but his performance wasn't included in the final mix. Timeline Photos.

We're sure that some of you are getting very excited now - later today, David Gilmour performs the final Royal Albert Hall show of the tour. Will you be one of those seeing this sight later today? Timeline Photos.

Here's yesterday morning's interview with David Gilmour and Polly Samson, on US television station CBS's This Morning. Ex-Pink Floyd guitarist David Gilmour on new solo album. Legendary guitarist David Gilmour, formerly of Pink Floyd, is out with his first solo album in nearly 10 years. Gilmour had never done an in-depth interview for U.S. television until now, and but Anthony Mason traveled to England and spoke to him about his career and latest album, "Rattle That Lock.…

Published today is the new issue of the UK's Mojo Magazine (cover date October 2015/issue 263), available online, worldwide, through
http://fave.co/1PFR0ss. The magazine includes a major new interview with David Gilmour, talking of various subjects including his forthcoming album, Rattle That Lock. Of particular interest to many will be the cover-mounted CD; a number of David's closest collaborators appear on their special compilation while the guitarist is featured on six of the tracks himself, including songs from Phil Manzanera, Robert Wyatt and The Pretty Things. There's also - unavailable elsewhere – David’s collaboration with his son Joe’s cover version of The Beatles'  song, Here, There And Everywhere. Timeline Photos.
Richard Wright was born on this day in 1943. What's your favourite song featuring Richard's talents? Timeline Photos.

In 2001, David appeared as part of the Robert Wyatt curated Meltdown Festival at the Royal Festival Hall in London. A recording of the concert was later released as David Gilmour In Concert, which can be bought on DVD, or as an interactive app for Android devices (http://bit.ly/1SDjyES) and also for Apple devices (http://fave.co/19EDxNq) Timeline Photos.

Today in 2006, David Gilmour performed the first of three consecutive nights at London's Royal Albert Hall. To mark the occasion, this picture was taken during the afternoon of the assembled musicians for that night's show, including Robert Wyatt, David Crosby, and David Bowie... (Graham Nash somehow managed to avoid the camera lens). Timeline Photos.
In 2001, Wouldn't You Miss Me? The Best Of Syd Barrett was released. A highlight of the release for Syd fans was the release of the song Bob Dylan Blues for the first time. Timeline Photos.
As you know, David Gilmour is performing a few shows in Europe in September this year. What tracks do you think, or hope, he performs during those concerts? Timeline Photos.
Please join us in wishing David Gilmour the happiest of birthdays. Today also marks the ninth anniversary of his third solo album, On An Island. Timeline Photos.

Today saw the first of five concerts for David Gilmour in 2002 - three nights in London, and two in Paris. There were some special guests on various nights: Kate Bush, Robert Wyatt and Bob Geldof, as well as the return to the stage of Richard Wright, which thrilled fans in attendance. Timeline Photos.

This day in 1968, at the University of Birmingham, fans saw the first of the handful of concerts which were performed by the five-piece Pink Floyd. This picture is one of a handful taken at the sole photo session undertaken when the band had both Syd Barrett, and David Gilmour, in their ranks. Timeline Photos.
Today we mark the day in 1946 that Roger Keith "Syd" Barrett was born. How will you be celebrating his birthday today? Timeline Photos.

The two auctions currently running on eBay, offering Storm Thorgerson signed Syd Barrett fine art prints (which Storm gave to Syd's sister, Rosemary) finish TODAY at 4pm UK time. The prints are being sold to raise money for charitable causes.

For the Introduction to Syd Barrett print, click here: http://fave.co/1DmbMaH

For the Tribute to Syd Barrett/Green Doors print, click here: http://fave.co/1FhHWpE. Timeline Photos.

Two Storm Thorgerson signed Syd Barrett fine art prints are being auctioned on eBay this week. The prints were given to Syd's sister, Rosemary, and she is now selling the prints to raise money for charitable causes. 

For the Introduction to Syd Barrett print, click here: http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/like/121463718648 

For the Tribute to Syd Barrett/Green Doors print, click here: http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/like/121463717138. Timeline Photos.

A collaboration in 1985 between Nick Mason and 10cc's guitarist Rick Fenn (who still performs with 10cc today) resulted in the album Profiles. The track Lie For A Lie (released as a single) included guest vocalists Maggie Reilly and David Gilmour, both of whom appeared in the promotional video... Timeline Photos.
Richard Wright was born on this day in 1943, and his contribution to Pink Floyd was immeasurable. What is your favourite performance of Richard's? Timeline Photos.

Some of you will recall Life In A Northern Town, the debut by Dream Academy, which was co-produced by David Gilmour, as was its accompanying album. Singer and co-composer Nick Laird-Clowes, known to Floyd fans for his contributions to The Division Bell, has announced a remastered collection of Dream Academy's work, The Morning Lasted All Day. 

It features 24 tracks on 2 CDs, including Life In A Northern Town, The Love Parade and previously unreleased tracks, including Living In A War and The Chosen Few, both of which feature David on guitar. Other guest musicians include Johnny Marr and Lindsey Buckingham.

The album will be available from July 29. For more information, click here: http://www.realgonemusic.com/news/2014/6/12/the-dream-academy.html. Timeline Photos.
Today we remember the very sad passing of Roger Keith "Syd" Barrett, who left us in 2006. Celebrate his legacy by sharing your favourite memory of Syd and his work. Timeline Photos.

Yesterday saw the release on 180g heavyweight vinyl of Syd Barrett's albums The Madcap Laughs, Barrett and the compilation Opel. Opel features unreleased material and alternate takes of recordings from sessions for 'Madcap' and 'Barrett'. Timeline Photos.

The last of three nights at the Royal Albert Hall at the end of May on the 2006 David Gilmour tour, saw Nick Mason joining the band on stage for encores of Wish You Were Here and Comfortably Numb. The concerts were recorded and released as Remember That Night on DVD and Blu-ray... Timeline Photos.

In 2006, David Gilmour performed the first of three consecutive nights at London's Royal Albert Hall, which included some special guests. Included amongst those on the first night was a very rare live appearance by David Bowie, and here's Brian Rasic's picture of the first night's stellar line-up, prior to the show: Timeline Photos.
In 1978, David Gilmour brought out his first solo album. The eponymous release seemed to take fans a little by surprise - evidenced by this advert issued by his US record company: Timeline Photos.

Incredibly, today marks the 30th anniversary of the release of the first Roger Waters solo album, The Pros and Cons of Hitchhiking. Also performing on the album was the legendary Eric Clapton, who joined Roger for his 1984 concerts. Here's a scarce shot of the pair of them on stage that year. Timeline Photos.

This week saw the release of Hendra, the latest solo album from Ben Watt. One of the tracks, The Levels, has a guest appearance by David Gilmour on slide guitar, and recently the track was performed "live" in David's studio. Here's a video of that performance: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WG2Xh523Dt0. Ben Watt with David Gilmour / 'The Levels' (Live) A special live stripped-back version of 'The Levels' featuring Ben on vocals and acoustic guitar, and Pink Floyd's David Gilmour on slide guitar, recorded at...

Today sees the release of Hendra, by Ben Watt, on CD and download. The album by the former member of Everything But The Girl includes a guest appearance by David Gilmour who adds plangent slide guitar and backing vocals to the track The Levels. Timeline Photos.

It's the 30th anniversary of the release of Identity, by Zee - a collaboration between Richard Wright, and Dave 'Dee' Harris. It's an album very much of its time, with music that Richard felt in retrospect wasn't an overly successful experiment. Despite that, it is still sought out by fans. It was to be twelve years until Richard's next solo album, Broken China, was released. Timeline Photos.

The publishers of the Syd Barrett book have launched a competition to win a copy of the Syd Barrett Signature Edition book, numbered 001. 

Only 500 of these these box set books were ever made and each is hand numbered and individually signed by one of Syd’s brothers or sisters. A celebration of Syd’s life before, during and after Pink Floyd, the book normally retails at £300/$500.
 
Its very simple to enter; just go to http://barrettbook.com/#win and fill in your name and email address. If you wish you can also get more chances to win using social media. Entries must be received before 12 noon (GMT) Thursday April 10. Timeline Photos.
Please join us in wishing David Gilmour a very happy 68th birthday today. It's also the anniversary of the release of his last solo album, On An Island, in 2006. Timeline Photos.
Today sees the 30th anniversary of the UK release of David Gilmour's second solo album, About Face. What's your favourite track from this album? Timeline Photos.

David Gilmour performed the first of three nights at London's Royal Festival Hall, on this day 12 years ago. Guests at the shows were Kate Bush, Bob Geldof, Robert Wyatt, and Richard Wright... Timeline Photos.
Today we celebrate Syd Barrett's birthday - he was born on January 6th, 1946. What track most sums up Syd's musical talents for you? Timeline Photos.
The Madcap Laughs, Syd Barrett's first solo album, was released in the UK on this day, 1970. Timeline Photos.

The acclaimed book 'Barrett, the Definitive Visual Companion', is now available at a 25% discount but only until December 8th. Classic Rock called the book "...an essential object for the Syd obsessive", Brain Damage said that it was "absolutely essential", and Mojo Magazine noted that "With the help of the Barrett family and friends, the authors have unearthed a remarkable haul of personal correspondence, previously unpublished photographs and images of all Syd’s known artwork. It's an extraordinary achievement. Beautifully packaged, eruditely written and full of insight, 'Barrett' feels like the ultimate work of art."

You can currently pick up the Classic Edition for £48.75, plus shipping, and the Limited Edition for £225, plus shipping. More details at http://barrettbook.com. Barrett. The definitive visual companion to the life of Syd Barrett. The definitive visual companion to the life of Syd Barrett.

Barrett, Syd's second solo album, was released on this day in 1970. It was his second and final studio album of new material, and was produced by David Gilmour (who played bass guitar on it), and included contributions from Richard Wright on keyboards and Jerry Shirley on drums. The cover was drawn by Barrett himself. Timeline Photos.

Today we remember Steve O'Rourke, Pink Floyd's manager from 1968 onwards, who passed away ten years ago. At his funeral, David Gilmour performed Fat Old Sun, and then Great Gig In The Sky, joined by Nick Mason and Richard Wright. A keen racing driver, he set up EMKA Racing in 1980 named after EMKA Productions, his management company. Timeline Photos.

With many apologies for the unforeseen delay, we are now happy to announce that the App created to enjoy ‘David Gilmour In Concert’ has now been approved by Apple. It follows its release for Android devices, and is now available for iPhone and iPad in their App Store, which operates in 155 countries.

Directed by David Mallet, the original programme's features have been retained in full. The concert songs are: Shine On You Crazy Diamond (Parts 1-5); Terrapin; Fat Old Sun; Coming Back To Life; High Hopes; Je Crois Entendre Encore; Smile; Wish You Were Here; Comfortably Numb (featuring Robert Wyatt); Dimming Of The Day; Shine On You Crazy Diamond (Parts 6-8); A Great Day For Freedom; Hushabye Mountain; Breakthrough (featuring Richard Wright); and Comfortably Numb (featuring Bob Geldof). Extras include: Spare Digits (closeups of David's guitar parts); Home Movie (shot at rehearsals); High Hopes Choral; I Put A Spell On You (with Jools Holland and Mica Paris); Don't; and Sonnet 18.

The first 13 songs (Shine On through to Hushabye Mountain) were shot in HD, with the remainder of the concert footage and the extras shot in standard definition. The App is full of rich video and audio material with interactive motion, menu navigation options and bonus extras. 

Find it on the App Store here: https://itunes.apple.com/gb/app/david-gilmour-in-concert/id718176469?mt=8&affId=1503186. Timeline Photos.
This track, Sysyphus, is also from Ummagumma, and is part of Richard Wright's contribution to the project. Sysyphus.

Pink Floyd played the second of a fifteen night run at Earls Court Exhibition Hall, Earls Court, London, England, during their Division Bell European tour, today in 1994. As well as the expected laser display, the show featured multi-coloured strobe lights, inflatable pigs, pyrotechnics and films shown on a 30-foot diameter screen. The set list was: Shine On You Crazy Diamond (Parts 1-3, 5 & 7), Learning To Fly, What Do You Want From Me?, On The Turning Away, Take It Back, Coming Back To Life, Sorrow, Keep Talking, One Of These Days, Astronomy Domine, Breathe, Time, Breathe (Reprise), High Hopes, The Great Gig In The Sky, Wish You Were Here, Us And Them, Money, Another Brick In The Wall (Part 2) and Comfortably Numb. The encores were Hey You and Run Like Hell.

For more information like this, check out the Official This Day In Pink Floyd app, available now for Apple iPad, iPhone and iTouch. There's plenty to explore and enjoy... http://itunes.apple.com/gb/app/this-day-in-pink-floyd/id476565133?mt=8 Timeline Photos.

Richard Wright's Broken China album from 1996 came out in the UK on this day. In one of the press adverts for it, there was the caption "Pink Floyd takes a break; Rick Wright breaks china...". Timeline Photos.
Today we mark the 5th anniversary of the very sad passing of Richard Wright. What are your fondest memories of Richard? Timeline Photos.

Nick Mason's 1985 album, Profiles, was released today, a collaboration with Rick Fenn and including guest performances from Mel Collins, Maggie Reilly, and a vocal from David Gilmour on Lie For A Lie. Timeline Photos.

Pink Floyd's first Australian tour kicked off today in 1971. They also appeared on ABC's GTK (Get To Know) television programme being interviewed: Pink Floyd - Interview 1971 Australian Tour (GTK on ABC) An interview conducted during their Australian tour in 1971, broadcast as part of a segment on GTK**, the ABC's music show of the period. (ABC = Australian B...

Richard Wright's second solo album, Broken China, was released in 1996 and quickly became a much loved package, from Storm Thorgerson and Peter Curzon's spectacular artwork, to some wonderful and typically evocative pieces of music. Here's the cover: Timeline Photos.
Today we remember Richard Wright, who was born on this day in 1943... Timeline Photos.
Wearing The Inside Out featured Richard Wright singing a lyric he wrote with Anthony Moore, for The Division Bell album. Here's an excerpt: Wearing The Inside Out.

The new issue of the UK's Record Collector magazine has a large and absorbing interview with Nick Mason, talking about a range of early Pink Floyd acetates, and his hopes for an Immersion set looking at the early years. There's also an interview with early producer Joe Boyd, and a guide to some of the rarer Pink Floyd vinyl releases, which includes the approximate value of these items. You can purchase the magazine in major UK stores now, or mail order via: http://recordcollectormag.com/issue-detail/417. Timeline Photos.
Today, in 2006, Roger Keith "Syd" Barrett sadly passed away. What Barrett song(s) are you playing today to remember him? Timeline Photos.

You can now get the informative 1960s Cambridge Music Scene Booklet, created by those who were there, in hard copy. As well as organising walking tours of Cambridge which highlight the places and events of Syd Barrett's early life, Warren Dosanjh, Stephen Pyle, Dave Parker and Tony Middleton edit the I-Spy Syd In Cambridge website, which includes an indepth study of the 1960s music scene in Cambridge, featuring many photos and running to some 72 pages.

The booklet has now been made available to buy as a hi-res printed version with a ring binding. Recently updated, it includes added pages on the Dawnbreakers, the Hi-Fi's, the Prowlers, Clive Welham and Johnny Cullum, as well as photos and stories of other Cambridge musical artists including Those Without, Jokers Wild, and many more.

The price is £15.00, which includes posting & packing in the UK only. Cheques should be made out to 'RCR2' and sent to 14 Greville Road, Cambridge CB1 3QL, accompanied by the name and address of the recipient. Warren Dosanjh advises that it would be helpful for orders to be collected by hand from the above address, if possible.

For countries outside the UK, please contact the site for a price inclusive of posting and packing here: 
http://www.i-spysydincambridge.com/contact. Timeline Photos.

David Gilmour's eponymous 1978 solo album was released on this day. Highlights include Short and Sweet, There's No Way Out of Here, and Cry From The Street, but what's your favourite track? Timeline Photos.

Today marks the 36th anniversary of the release of Pink Floyd's Animals. This was a slightly unexpected, but certainly eyecatching advert for the album in the UK's New Musical Express weekly newspaper. Timeline Photos.
Today, we mark the anniversary of Roger Keith "Syd" Barrett's birthday. Timeline Photos.
Forty-three years ago today, Syd Barrett's first solo album, The Madcap Laughs, was released in the UK. What's your favourite track on this album? Timeline Photos.
Today marks the anniversary of the 1971 release of Pink Floyd's album, Meddle. One of the key tracks, of course, is the side-long Echoes... Timeline Photos.

On this day in 1996, Richard Wright's second solo album, Broken China, was released. With a Storm Thorgerson cover, and a guest vocal from Sinead O'Connor, it's a favourite with many Floyd fans. Timeline Photos.
Today we remember founder member of Pink Floyd, Richard Wright, who sadly passed away in 2008. Timeline Photos.
Today we remember Richard Wright, who was born on this day in 1943. Timeline Photos.
Today we remember Roger Keith "Syd" Barrett, who very sadly passed away on this day in 2006. Timeline Photos.
See Emily Play, backed with The Scarecrow, was released as a UK single today in 1967. The cover was drawn by Syd Barrett... Timeline Photos.
Today in 1978, David Gilmour released his first, eponymous solo album in the UK. Timeline Photos.

In a special Games for May celebration, Essential Works are offering the acclaimed, limited edition 'Barrett' book at a huge 50% reduction, this weekend only. Mojo magazine called the book "...an extraordinary achievement", Classic Rock said is "...an essential object for the Syd obsessive”, and Brain Damage noted that it was "absolutely essential". 

The discount means you can pick up the Classic Edition book for just £35 and the Signature Edition for only £150. There is also an option to split your purchase into three instalments over three months. The offers run from now until midday GMT on Tuesday May 8th – so act quickly to get your copy before they sell out. For more details, visit barrettbook.com. Barrett. The definitive visual companion to the life of Syd Barrett. The definitive visual companion to the life of Syd Barrett.
Fat Old Sun is a track from the band's 1970 album, Atom Heart Mother, and features Richard Wright on keyboards, and David Gilmour performing all other instrumentation... Pink Floyd - Fat Old Sun.
Richard Wright's contribution to Pink Floyd was huge. What is your favourite vocal or musical performance (Floyd or solo) of Richard's?
This track is taken from The Division Bell, and features a Richard Wright vocal... Pink Floyd - Wearing The Inside Out.
In 1973, Pink Floyd's The Dark Side Of The Moon was released in the UK on this day. Timeline Photos.

Last night, London's Hammersmith Apollo saw friends from comedy, music and science come together to celebrate the life of Douglas Adams, who would have been celebrating his 60th birthday. As part of the show, David Gilmour made a guest appearance, performing on three songs - Wish You Were Here, Too Much Monkey Business, and A Whiter Shade Of Pale. Fansite Brain Damage have reviewed the show, and they have pictures of David and the band in action: David Gilmour performs at the Douglas Adams 60th Birthday Party. 11 March 2012 would have been Douglas Adams' 60th Birthday. To celebrate this event, Douglas's fami....

To help mark tomorrow's 6th anniversary of the release of David Gilmour's album 'On An Island', and his birthday, for 48 hours there is a free download and stream of the track 'A Pocketful Of Stones'. The download becomes available at midnight tonight from David's website, and if you've not heard the track before, we hope you enjoy it. It features Polish classical/jazz musician Leszek Mozdzer on piano, Alasdair Malloy on glass harmonica and David on guitars, percussion, Hammond organ and bass, as well as vocals.

It will be available until 11:59pm GMT (UK time) on Wednesday 7th March. David Gilmour | The Voice and Guitar of Pink Floyd | Official Website. David Gilmour is a guitarist and vocalist with British rock band Pink Floyd, and was voted No. 1 in Fender's Greatest Players poll in the February 2006 Guitarist magazine in the UK.
This day in 1984 saw the release of David Gilmour's second solo album, About Face. Amongst the guest musicians were Steve Winwood, Ray Cooper, Jon Lord and Roy Harper... Timeline Photos.
Animals was released in the UK on this day in 1977... Timeline Photos.
On this day in 1973, Clare Torry recorded her vocal for Pink Floyd's The Great Gig In The Sky. Pink Floyd - The Great Gig In The Sky.

Dear, dear, were they really sad for me?

Another anniversary - today marks 20 years since the release of Pink Floyd's final album, The Division Bell. The band struggled to find a suitable title, considering things like Pow Wow and Down To Earth. Eventually, with the promise of a donation to his favourite charity The Environmental Investigation Agency, the writer Douglas Adams came up with The Division Bell as his suggested title, which the band liked. Today in 2006, a pair of signed Pink Floyd giant eyeballs, one of only ten pairs, was auctioned on eBay in aid of the UK's homelessness charity Crisis (http://www.crisis.org.uk), of which David Gilmour was made a vice president back in 2003. David said: "The eBay auction will not only raise much needed funds for the charity, but will also raise awareness of the plight of the homeless at a time of year when they are most vulnerable".

The eyeballs, approximately six feet high, were signed by David, Richard Wright and Nick Mason, along with designer Storm Thorgerson. They were autographed at the July press launch in London of the PULSE double DVD. They sold for £16,500. Timeline Photos.

This morning, Roger Waters and Nick Mason unveiled this commemorative plaque which has been installed onto the front of the University of Westminster (formerly known as the Regent Street Polytechnic) in London. It was whilst studying there that Roger, Nick and Richard Wright met, later leading to the forming of Pink Floyd. Photos from Pink Floyd's post.

The UK's BBC Radio 4 spoke to Nick Mason and Roger Waters this morning, at the unveiling of a plaque commemorating Pink Floyd's beginnings at the Regent Street Polytechnic. Their Front Row programme, which airs at 7:15pm BST, includes the interview - for those unable to hear it live, the show will be available in full on demand after broadcast. Visitors to London between now and the end of the year will find, in various locations, more than fifty specially designed statues of the character Paddington Bear - including one designed by Nick Mason which uses Wish You Were Here as its inspiration (with his suitcase having various backstage passes affixed), and can be found at the O2 Arena. The bears form The Paddington Trail, a fundraising effort to benefit the NSPCC (National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children) and children's charity Action Medical Research for whom Paddington Bear has been the official mascot for over 35 years.

There will be an auction for the statues and some of the more collectable items. It is hoped that The Paddington Trail and associated activities will raise over £500,000.
http://www.nspcc.org.uk/fighting-for-childhood/news-opinion/join-paddington-trail/?affId=1991357. Timeline Photos.

A message from Roger Waters: Roger Waters. A note from Roger:
Check out the CNN site http://heroes.cnn.com. It mentions my friend Arthur Bloom, the leader of Musicorps at Walter Reed Hospital, who has been nominated as Top Hero of 2014. I have worked with Arthur and many amazing vet musicians over the last few years. They are my brothers, I love them. If Arthur wins this CNN thing the vet music program will get $100,000. Please vote over the next days to register your support.

Arthur is one of ten nominees, I am sure the other nine are all very worthy, so I apologize for declaring my support for my particular brothers without due debate. The fact is we must all give our love and support to our brothers and sisters wherever and whenever we can.

Love
Roger.

Potsdamer Platz in Berlin on this day, 1990, saw a huge performance of The Wall, performed by Roger Waters and his band, along with guests such as Van Morrison, Joni Mitchell, Bryan Adams and The Scorpions. The show was broadcast live worldwide, and typically there were power issues early on - with no sound, Roger improvised with a bit of tap-dancing to entertain the 350,000+ audience there, and the millions around the world. Timeline Photos.

On this day in 2010, Roger Waters and David Gilmour performed together for the Hoping Foundation Benefit Evening, at Kiddington Hall in Oxfordshire, England. A deal was struck between Roger and David so that in return for Roger's appearance at the Benefit, David would guest in one of Roger's then-upcoming Wall shows. Timeline Photos.

Pink Floyd can confirm that they are releasing a new album "The Endless River" in October 2014. It is an album of mainly ambient and instrumental music based on the 1993/4 Division Bell sessions which feature David Gilmour, Nick Mason and Richard Wright. The album is produced by David Gilmour with Phil Manzanera, Youth and recording engineer Andy Jackson. Work is still in progress, but more details to come at the end of the Summer.

Nick Mason, on the 1968 Hyde Park Free Concert which happened on this day: 
"The one in '68 was wonderful because it was much more a picnic in the park than a mini-Woodstock. A lovely day. It was important for us too because it reminded us of our roots - whether spurious or not. They were our roots - not personally, but as an enterprise. We were the house band." Timeline Photos.

David Gilmour:
"We used to make up tapes for the audience to come in by. We had one half-hour long tape, which we'd play for the half an hour the audience was coming in just before we started our show, and things like that. Just tapes of bird noises in quad -- quadraphonic sound, you know, with birds singing, and pheasants taking off in the distance, and swans taking off from water, a tractor driving down one side of the room, and an airplane going over the top, and all these things carrying on, all just from just different sound effects records, you just stick them in and you -- you create a type of mood..." 
The Source, US Radio 1984.

War Child is working with renowned British artist Tim Wakefield on a project called "Soundwaves" to celebrate and promote the work of iconic musicians. Tim has ten prints of the "Careful With That Axe, Eugene" soundwave image shown here, signed by Nick Mason, and is selling them online in aid of War Child's Children of Syria Appeal. This aims to raise funds for a new project with Syrian children outside of the refugee camps, where thousands of children remain inaccessible to services or too hidden to receive help. All donations to War Child's appeal will be matched pound-for-pound by the UK Government. Also included in this online sale are 19 other pieces of Soundwaves art inspired by the music of Queen, Brian Wilson, Eric Clapton and many more. The sale will run through to January 31st, 2014, and can be found at http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/soundwaves-art. Timeline Photos.

Quote of the day:

On the band's lack of special stage clothing: "We are convinced that dressing for a show doesn't help the music we perform. The images and the lights help you to perceive the music. The public watches the images on the screen and doesn't have time to divert their attention to our dress..."
Nick Mason, Ciao 2001, May 1975.

Quote of the day:

“We are simply a pop group. But because we use light and colour in our act, a lot of people seem to imagine that we are trying to put across some message with nasty, evil undertones.” 
Roger Waters, New Musical Express, July 1967.

On this day in 2005, Roger Waters released Ça Ira, an opera in three parts about the French Revolution. The libretto was co-written by Etienne and Nadine Roda-Gil, who approached Roger, asking him to set their work to music. Since its release it has had regular performances, often with full dramatic staging to bring the story more to life. Here's Roger talking about it:
http://vimeo.com/45036779. Roger Waters Ca Ira. EPK Director: Jimmy ienner, Jr. Executive Producer: Roger Waters Producer: David Silver Editors: Caroline Buckler / Rick Broat Sony Classical & Columbia Records TRT:7:55.

Quote of the day: 

"One of the myths about the Pink Floyd is that they have all this amazing electronic gadgetry when, in fact, we all use the same as any other group. It’s our technique of using them in a different way…" 

Roger Waters, New Musical Express, June 1972.

Rockarchive, the rock photography collective and gallery network, have announced that Nick Mason will be holding a signing at their pop-up gallery in Monmouth St, WC2 on Thursday 30th May, between 5 and 6pm.

Nick will be visiting the Rockarchive pop-up shop to sign an edition of 50 exclusive photographic prints of himself, made specially for the occasion and available at a reduced price of £100 for the night only. Pink Floyd fans are also invited to bring along one item of personal Pink Floyd memorabilia that they wish to be autographed. On display will also be an extensive collection of Pink Floyd prints displayed in the gallery, plus there will be the chance to enter a raffle to win a signed pair of Nick’s drum sticks.

All prints displayed at the Rockarchive Pop-up Gallery are being sold at a 20% discount for the evening.

Address is: Rockarchive Pop Up Gallery, 46 Monmouth Street, Seven Dials, London WC2H 9EP. The gallery is open every day from 11am – 7pm until Monday 3rd June 2013.

Rockarchive's online site is at www.rockarchive.com. Timeline Photos.

A Personal Statement from Roger Waters

"Tribunal Epilogue"
The great Jewish-American writer, professor, human rights activist, Nobel Laureate, and holocaust survivor, Elie Wiesel, the author of 'Night', famously wrote:
"..TO REMAIN SILENT AND INDIFFERENT IS THE GREATEST SIN OF ALL."
How right he was, and is. It is with great respect for Mr Wiesel and also for Bertrand Russell, the British philosopher and tireless advocate for human rights, who set up the first Russell Tribunal back in 1966 to protest the Vietnam war, that I presume to address these remarks to you, today.

Love
Roger

Watch as the largest Wall staging of the entire tour to date is built. The official Roger Waters The Wall Facebook page will be posting pictures throughout the day leading up to the show in Quebec City this Saturday. Tickets still available -http://bit.ly/rwquebec. Timeline Photos.

ROGER WATERS - THE WALL

THE PLAINS OF ABRAHAM – QUEBEC CITY

SATURDAY JULY 21st, 2012

An historic performance of ‘Roger Waters – The Wall’ will take place in Québec City on Saturday July 21st. This final date of the 2012 tour will feature the largest wall ever built.

Roger Waters says: “I’ve always loved playing in Québec. The Québécois are a very passionate and musical people and we’ll be playing on the Fields of Abraham. This is going to be completely unlike any of The Wall shows we’ve done anywhere else in the world.“

A limited number of priority tickets (wristbands) will be available in advance of the public sale for fans who register on RogerWaters.com between 9:00am on Wednesday May 23rd and 9pm Thursday May 31st.

Fans who have purchased a pass for this year’s Festival d’été de Québec can also get priority booking by registering online at www.infofestival.com during the same time period.

General public sales will commence on June 5th at www.infofestival.com

Sunday evening, Bristol's Watershed is the host of a screening of Ron Geesin: An Improvised Life, followed by a Q&A with the man himself. Ron, of course, was a key part of the Atom Heart Mother project, amongst other things. Tickets are now available from the venue: http://www.watershed.co.uk/whatson/7243/an-improvised-life-plus-qa-with-ron-geesin. Filmic: An Improvised Life plus Q&A with Ron Geesin. Warm profile of the idiosyncratic musician, film composer, and sound sculptor Ron Geesin, best known for his profound orchestral collaboration with Pink Floyd on their first No. 1 album Atom Heart Mother.
The unusual nature of Pink Floyd's Atom Heart Mother cover provided some interesting possibilities to the marketing teams... Timeline Photos.

Headlining a benefit concert in 1970, Pink Floyd played their part in a 12-hour show which also included Ron Geesin (Music From The Body, Atom Heart Mother) and listed at the bottom of the bill, Black Sabbath. Timeline Photos.

A new film reveals exclusive 2008 footage of David Gilmour performing in a full-scale revival of Atom Heart Mother in London. Ron Geesin: An Improvised Life documents the life of the Pink Floyd collaborator. The film's world premiere will be in London on Saturday 3 October at 5pm, and after the screening, Ron will undertake a Q&A session. 

In the film, Ron describes how Pink Floyd asked him to develop the orchestral score, talks us through the writing process, the recording at Abbey Road and explains how a pint with a friend at the local pub led to the revival concert. Elsewhere in the documentary, David Gilmour explains why he agreed to become the special guest.

The film also includes interviews with Nick Mason, Pete Townshend, Peter Gabriel, Robert Wyatt and Bridget St John.

More information can be found here: http://www.geesinimprovlife.com. Ron Geesin | An Improvised Life.

Atom Heart Mother propelled Pink Floyd to stardom and became the band’s first UK #1 album.

New book The Flaming Cow, to be published in July, offers a rare insight into the brilliant but often fraught collaboration between Pink Floyd and composer Ron Geesin, the result of which became known as Atom Heart Mother. The book, with a foreword by Nick Mason, is an unflinching account about how one of Pink Floyd’s most celebrated compositions came to life.

Ron Geesin, author of The Flaming Cow, will be answering a selection of your questions in an exclusive Q&A next week, and the answers will be included in the enhanced eBook available on the iBookstore. Submit your questions here…. Timeline Photos.

Pink Floyd performed in Offenbach, West Germany in 1971, with a German TV crew present, and showcasing Atom Heart Mother, complete with brass and choir conducted by Jeffrey Mitchell. Other tracks included The Embryo, Cymbaline, and a Blues jam as part of the encore. Timeline Photos.

Pink Floyd's album Atom Heart Mother was released in the UK on this day in 1970. It was their first number one album, despite the cover which had just the simple, but very striking, picture of a black and white cow, on it. The record company weren't impressed by the cover at the time, but it has become one of the band's iconic images. Featuring extensive collaboration with Ron Geesin, it showed the band moving in a new direction with their music. Timeline Photos.

On this day in 1970, Pink Floyd recorded a live set at KQED Studios in San Francisco, with no audience. It was later aired on PBS television. Pink Floyd - Atom Heart Mother. From the 1970 Pink Floyd album, Atom Heart Mother.

summary: The Pink Floyd Exhibition: Their Mortal Remains.

V&A #ArchiveMyMemory: My Pink Floyd memory

To celebrate the upcoming exhibition The Pink Floyd Exhibition: Their Mortal Remains, the Victoria and Albert Museum, London, is asking the people who know the band best – the fans – why Pink Floyd are so important.

messages: There's now around two months to go until The Pink Floyd Exhibition: Their Mortal Remains opens at the Victoria & Albert Museum in London. What would be your three dream items to see at the exhibition? More information about Their Mortal Remains can be found at http://www.pinkfloydexhibition.com. Timeline Photos.

Get a rare and exclusive glimpse into one of the world’s most iconic rock groups, only at The Pink Floyd Exhibition. 

#TheirMortalRemains is an audio-visual journey through 50 years of Pink Floyd’s history, connecting with music, art and design, sound technology and live performance: from their beginnings on the underground club scene in 1960s London to the present day.

The Pink Floyd Exhibition: Their Mortal Remains opens on 13 May at London’s Victoria and Albert Museum for 20 weeks only.

Book now at http://po.st/PFE to avoid disappointment.

Roger Waters and Nick Mason [pictured here - photo: Jill Furmanovsky] made a rare public appearance together today at London’s May Fair Hotel at a media briefing and Q&A session for The Pink Floyd Exhibition: Their Mortal Remains, due to open in May at London’s V&A museum. Hosted by DJ Matt Everitt, the event started with a short description of the exhibition by co-curator Victoria Broackes, outlining the attention to detail that has gone into every aspect. 

This was followed by a Question & Answer session with Matt and Pink Floyd’s Creative Director Aubrey ‘Po’ Powell of Hipgnosis, alongside Ray Winkler, CEO of the exhibition’s designers Stufish. Po spoke evocatively and warmly of his personal history with the members of Pink Floyd, and with Syd Barrett in particular, providing a creative and cultural overview of the ups, downs and importance of Pink Floyd’s career, while Ray Winkler touched on the design and architectural elements of Pink Floyd’s live staging.

Daniel Sennheiser, CEO of audio electronics company Sennheiser, then talked about the company's involvement with Pink Floyd from their earliest years, and their shared commitment to audio excellence, which will manifest itself in 360-degree audio mixes played in a portion of the exhibition, as well as the headphone technology used to provide aural accompaniment to the exhibits.

Finally, Roger and Nick took to the stage to answer questions from Matt Everitt and some media in the audience. With thoughtful, and occasionally hilarious, answers, they covered topics such as playing specific concerts and Roger’s forthcoming album, to be entitled ‘Is This The Life We Really Want?’, while Nick admitted that he was probably the member of Pink Floyd most likely to have kept photos and memorabilia. Both of them professed their admiration for the V&A curation team in unearthing interesting and meaningful objects, whether historic personal letters from the band or the actual cane used to beat Roger at Cambridgeshire High School For Boys, accompanied by the school’s ‘Punishment Book’ listing the beatings. 

They both looked forward to viewing the exhibition in person, including passing through the entrance, a special reconstruction of the band’s Bedford CA van, into a world of Pink Floyd history, starting with psychedelia and progressing to the ambitious stagings of the later years.

The Pink Floyd Exhibition: Their Mortal Remains, presented by the V&A and Michael Cohl’s Iconic Entertainment Studios, runs from the 13th May till the 1st October 2017.

Tickets are on sale now: in person at the V&A; online at vam.ac.uk/pink-floyd or by calling (In the UK ) 0800 912 6961 (booking fee applies); or from ticketing partners Ticketmaster, LOVETheatre, See Tickets and Encore

London’s Victoria and Albert Museum today announced the first major international retrospective of Pink Floyd. To mark 50 years since the band released their first single Arnold Layne, and over 200 million record sales later, The Pink Floyd Exhibition: Their Mortal Remains will be an immersive, multi-sensory and theatrical journey through Pink Floyd’s extraordinary world. 

A story of sound, design and performance, the exhibition will chronicle the music, iconic visuals and staging of the band, from the underground psychedelic scene in 1960s London to the present day, illustrating their groundbreaking use of special effects, sonic experimentation, powerful imagery and social commentary. The exhibition marks the first collaboration in decades of Pink Floyd’s remaining members and is promoted by Michael Cohl and Iconic Entertainment Studios. 

The Pink Floyd Exhibition: Their Mortal Remains opens on 13 May 2017 and runs until 1 October. Tickets go on sale at 10am today, via the V&A and other ticketing partners.

More information can be found at http://www.pinkfloydexhibition.com and at https://shop.vam.ac.uk/whatson/index/view/id/3555/event/Pink-Floyd--Their-Mortal-Remains/dt/2017-05-13/free/2. #TheirMortalRemains. Pink Floyd Exhibition | Victoria and Albert Museum.

Milan, October 13th, 2014 – Evolve Devolve, the Italian promoters of "The Pink Floyd Exhibition - Their Mortal Remains", have announced today that the exhibition, due to take place from September 19th in Milan, has now been cancelled because the necessary conditions have not occurred in order to make it happen within the time frame available at the Fabbrica del Vapore. (These conditions have nothing to do with Milan's Municipality).

Ticket holders for the exhibition should seek refunds from their point of purchase according to the procedures already communicated.

Milan is clearly getting itself into a Pink Floyd frame of mind. With the Italian city in the midst of preparing for the hugely anticipated launch of The Pink Floyd Exhibition - Their Mortal Remains (http://www.pinkfloydexhibition.com), which opens in September, there's a set of opportunities for those who can get there this month to celebrate the band's music.

Running until June 20th at the legendary Teatro alla Scala is a joint production of a Jean Cocteau piece, along with the late Roland Petit's Pink Floyd Ballet. First performed in 1972, it's the perfect blend of dance and music, and as with the exhibition (which runs until January 2015) tickets are now available. More details here:

In 1967, Pink Floyd played at the Agincourt Ballroom in Camberley, England. This venue had been a morgue during the Second World War and was said to be haunted by a little girl, seen many times by the staff there. The chances of her name being Emily are remote, as are the possibilities that the band's concert included an appearance by her! On this day in 1994, as part of The Division Bell tour, Pink Floyd played at the famous Hockenheimring motor racing circuit in Germany. This was not the first time that the band had made an appearance at a track, though. In June 1967 they appeared (but didn't perform) in a parade in an open topped car for the Radio London Motor Racing & Pop Festival, at England's Brands Hatch circuit. Pink Floyd continued recording sessions for the Household Objects album on this day in 1973. After the success of The Dark Side Of The Moon the band returned to their experimental beginnings and began work on these sessions, which consisted of songs constructed entirely from sounds made by household appliances, including wine glasses, floor brushes and rubber bands. The project was eventually abandoned after only three tracks were recorded, although the wine glasses were used to create the opening glistening, ethereal effect at the start of Shine On You Crazy Diamond on 1975's Wish You Were Here.

This evening, KOKO, in London's Camden, saw a diverse bill for a truly thought provoking evening of music, film and speech. The evening was part of the Staging A Revolution: I'm With The Banned series of events run by Belarus Free Theatre.

Participants included groups who are banned from performing in their own countries. Joining them was David Gilmour, Jon Carin and Bryan Chambers performing with Boombox in a set which treated the capacity crowd to a rousing Astronomy Domine, In Any Tongue, Wish You Were Here and the title track from the new album, Rattle That Lock. The last song of the night included backing vocals by Polly and other Gilmour family members and friends.  For a selection of pictures taken during the sound check and concert itself, view the gallery here (http://on.fb.me/1GlaSk9) and for more information on the Belarus Free Theatre visit http://www.belarusfreetheatre.com.
